newsitem.title: USA: El Paso buys into Pakistani power project.
newsitem.headline: El Paso buys into Pakistani power project.

text.p: El Paso Energy Corp said Tuesday its international unit has purchased an interest in a consortium which will construct a $170 million power plant in Kabirwala, Punjab Province, Pakistan.
Construction on the 151 megawatt combined-cycle power facility will begin in January 1997, with start-up slated for November 1998, El Paso said.
The company said it will own a 42 percent interest in the plant. Its partners are the Fauji Foundation of Pakistan and the Asian Development Bank, which hold 45 percent and 13 percent, respectively.

Pakistan's state-owned Oil & Gas Development Corporation will supply natural gas to fuel the plant, and its Water and Power Development Authority will purchase power from the plant, for use in industrial, commercial and residential markets under a 30-year contract.

The company also noted its Tenneco Gas Pipeline Co subsidiary is constructing a 135 megawatt combined cycle power plant in South Sulawesi, Indonesia, as part of a $225 million integrated infrastructure project that includes ownership and development of a 600 billion cubic foot natural gas field and a 25-mile pipeline to link the reserves with the plant.
